div3.head: Message of the Governor of South Carolina.
div3.p:
In a message, on Tuesday last, to the Legislature of South Carolina, the new Governor of that State, General M. L. Bonham, earnestly recommends the repeal of the act requiring the Adjutant General of the State to order an election for field officers of the several regiments of the 1st Corps of Reserves, and of such other regiments now in service, whose field officers had been appointed by the Executive Council.
The reason assigned for this recommendation is an absence of power to order an election for field officers of regiments transferred to the Confederate service.
The Governor says that whatever opinion he may entertain as to the propriety of the field officers of these regiments being elected in the first instance, he believes it to be the true policy, under existing circumstances, to allow matters to stand as they are. He concludes his message with an injunction to harmony and concert with the Confederate Government.

div3.head: Col. Zarvona.
div3.p:
A letter from New York, published in the Baltimore Sun, of the instant, says:A released Fort Lafayette prisoner says that there are still in the fort about 35 prisoners, but mostly Confederates.
Prominent among them as the oldest inhabitants are Col. Zarvona, better known as the French lady, and Mr. John Hipkins, Jr., of Norfolk, Va.--Col. Zarvona is still in solitary confinement and suffering the same punishment he has undergone for ten months. No prisoner is allowed to see or communicate with him, and therefore his present condition is not precisely known.

div3.head: General Assembly of Virginia.
div3.p: Senate.--The Senate was called to order at 12 M. by Mr. Johnson, of Bedford, with prayer by Rev. C. H. Read.

The Senate was notified that the House had agreed to certain resolutions relative to Government impressments.
Referred to Committee on Confederate Relations.
A communication from the Governor transmitting list of, pardons and reprieves granted since the last session with reasons therefor, was read and ordered to be printed.
Mr. Brannon offered a resolution inquiring into the expediency of authorizing the sale of the slave convicts in the penitentiary, which was agreed to.
Mr. Lynch offered a resolution, which was agreed to, inquiring into the expediency of establishing an inspection for salt obtained from the Washington and Smyth mines.
On motion of Mr. Christian of Augusta, a special committee was charged with the duty of inquiring into the expediency of increasing the salaries of Judges and other State officers during the war.
The Committee on Finance and Claims were discharged from the further consideration of the petition of the assistant keepers of the Virginia penitentiary for increase of pay.
The petition, &c., of E. S. Arnold, late Sheriff of Kanawha asking to be refunded certain taxes paid by him into the Treasury, was presented by Mr. Pate, of Boone.

The resolution directing an inquiry into the expediency of amending the 1st section of an act passed March 12th, 1862, entitled "An act to prevent the unnecessary consumption of grain by dislitters and other manufacturers of spirituous and malt liquors, "so as to authorize the distillation into whiskey or other spirituous or malt liquors of so much corn aye," wheat, or other grain, as would be sufficient for the raising and fattening of the hogs owned by each individual owning or operating a distillery, was referred to the Committee on General Laws.
The petition of certain inspectors of Tobacco in Warehouses in Lynchburg for increase of compensation was referred to Committee on Agriculture and Commerce.
The resolution relative to voting a sum for the relief of Virginia soldiers in the C. B. army or State line, was referred to the Committee on Military Affairs.

The following hills were reported: To increase the foes and compensation of clerks of courts and constables; for the relief of Jaslah Wynn, of Lee county; for the relief of James M. Laldles; to authorize the sale of the lands of the Hillsboro' and Cincinnati Railroad Company, now owned by the State; amending and re-enacting an Ordinance of the Convention concerning.
Aid to the Governor, establishing an agency, in the city of Richmond, for recovering and forwarding clothing, shoes, and other supplies to Virginia soldiers; amending and receding the 4th section of 23d chapter of Code of Virginia; amending 15th section, chapter 23d of the Code; so as to allow of but one Major to each regiment.

Mr. Alderson presented the petition of Alfred Bickley, Brigadier General commanding 27th Brigade V. M., for compensation.
Referred to Committee on Military Affairs.
On motion of Mr. Nash, the Senate adjourned.

House of Delegates.--The House met at 12 o'clock M, Mr. Hopkins, of Petersburg, in the chair.
Prayer by Rev. Mr. Peterkin.
Senate bill allowing Sarah T. Thornton to remove certain slaves from this State to North Carolina, was taken up and passed.

The Senate bill making Lieut E. S. Gay commandant of the Public Guard, with an amendment by Mr. Wynn, that nothing contained therein shall operate to diminish the pay, rank, &c., of Colonel Dimmock, whenever he shall return to assume command of the same, was taken up and passed.

Mr. Dunn submitted a resolution, which was agreed to inquiring into the expediency of so changing the Code of Virginia as to allow guardian, during the continuance of this war, to invest the funds of their wards in Confederate State bonds.
A message was received from the Governor stating the number of pardons and reprieves granted by him the past year, together with his reasons therefor.

Mr. Valden submitted a resolution, instructing our senators and requesting our representatives in Congress to urge upon that body the necessity and justice of increasing the pay of all non- commissioned officers and privates who may be in the public service on the 1st day of March, 1863.

Mr. Worsham was in favor of the increase of pay, but did not think any further legislation was necessary on the part of the Legislature to accomplish it. The matter was already in the hard of Congress and our representatives, he believed, were doing all in their power to accomplish the object contemplated by the resolution; he, therefore, moved their indefinite postponement.

Mr. Hunter advocated the postponement, because the representatives were "all right" upon the subject, and he feared that these frequent instructions would against rather than facilitate an increase of pay.
Mr. Lockridge moved the previous question upon the indefinite postponement, and the postponement was concurred in.

The Clerk proceeded to call up the business from the Calendar, when the bitten larging the powers of the Common Council of the city of Richmond, for the suppression of riots, geming, and the sale of spirituous, liquors, was read a second time and laid upon the table.
A bill for the relief of the Clerks of the Hustings Court of Richmond was passed.
At one o'clock, on motion of Mr. Clarks, the House adjourned, for the purpose of allowing such members as might be disposed to do so attend the funeral of the late Major Wheat.

div3.head: The arrest of Rev. J. R. Graves.
div3.p:
--Governor Vance, of North Carolina, transmits to the Legislature of that State a letter received from the Secretary of War giving the causes of the arrest of J. R. Graves charged with disloyalty.
The letter states that wised applying to Gen. Winder for a passport to proceed North, he represented himself as a citizen of New York, desirous to return home, and in that character received permission.
After his return to the South, he published a letter in the Richmond Inquirer on the state of public opinion in the North, which gave a most unfavorable aspect to the Southern cause and caused much comment and inquiry as to the antecedents of the writer., Gen. Winder received several letters stating facts which gave good grounds for suspecting Craves to be a py or at least a disaffected person.
An exchanged prisoner from Fortress Monroe heard Craves give the Yankee officers a minute description of the warms comer building at Richmond, and, upon being shown diagrams of the Monitor, described where the Confederate steamer differed from her.

This charge was substantiated by Graves himself, he having stated to a clergyman of his acquaintance that he bad given such information, but merely to facilitate his passage North.
This and other instances of his more than suspicious conduct and conversation, convinced General Winder that it was unsafe to permit him to be at large.
He accordingly without consulting the Government at Richmond, but merely on his own authority, dispatched an officer to arrest him, considering him on his own representation when he asked a passport as a Northern citizen, and therefore liable to arrest as a spy. General Winder was not aware be was a citizen of North Carolina, when he issued the warrant, and was led into the mistake by the false representations of Graves himself.
The Secretary acknowledges that Gen. Winder was in error and expresses, the respect for the rights of the Sovereign States of the Confederate and states that he had for the very to receive him.

The 17 years locusts will appear this year.
Their law appearance was in May, 1846.
There is great distress in in many districts the people are actually starving.

div3.head: The Crisis of the American war.
div3.p:
For the first time the Confederates carried the war into the enemy's country.
They assumed the offensive and crossed over to Maryland.
If they counted on a movement in their favor on the part of the Marylanders, they were mistaken.
More probably their object was to capture Sarper's Ferry, which could not be taken except in rear, by crossing the Potomac, and also to secure supplies, of which they were very much in want.
One advantage, however, of unquestionable political importance was gained by this brief invasion of Maryland.
It demonstrated to the North, in a most unequivocal manner, the greatness of the triumphs achieved by the Confederate in the battles in Virginia; and it also removed a dilemma in the negotiations which must conclude the war. It gave to people of Maryland an opportunity of showing their adhesion to the Southern cause; and, as they did not respond to it, they cannot complain it at the close of the contest, the boundary line is drawn in such a manner as shall leave them still under the jurisdiction of the Northern Government.
That the Confederate General did not intend the invasion of Maryland to be more than a temporary movement, or a tentative experiment, is evidenced by the fact that his advanced guard had commenced a retrograde movement before McClellan's army came into collision with it; and when General Lee resolved to give battle at Antietam, he had to call up several corps of his army, which were still on the Potomac.
General Lee gave battle at Antietam for the same reasons as Wellington gave battle at Busaco.
On both of these occasions the General who gave battle intended to continue his retreat; but, finding himself in a good position, Lee, like Welington, gave battle in order to keep up the morale of his army, and, by giving a decided check to the enemy, gain the opportunity of withdrawing his army across the Potomac without molestation.
In this he was entirely successful.
With an inferior force he inflicted a bloody repulse upon the Federate, and then retired unassailed and in perfect order, to the Southern bank of the river.

Such was the position of the war at the close of the third week of September.
In the Border States to the West--Kentucky, Tennessee, and Missouri--the war is conducted in a desullory fashion, by a number of detached corps; but there also the balance of success had inclined greatly in favor of the Confederated.
The North beheld with rage and chagrin that all its vast armaments had been unable to accomplish any thing; and that, after a year and a half of hostilities and after incurring an enormous amount of debt, tis hopes of success had almost vanished.
Discontent was spreading everywhere, and every section of the discontented blamed the Government for not embrating its peculiar views of policy.
The Governors of sixteen of the States which adhere to the Union were to meet at Altdona on the 24th September--a manifest sign of grant of confidence in the Government — and the whole fabric of the Presidential power seemed ready to give way before a strong gust of popular dissatisfaction.
The President felt that something must be done.
The people clamored, as they always do in emergencies, for extreme measures; and the only extreme measure which he had left to employ was to proclaim the emancipation of the negroes.
He had previously, with the general concurrence of the people, inaugurated a dictatorship, abolished liberty, and installed force as the supreme power in the States which still adhered to the Union.
He had practically abolished the habeas corpus act, and introduced the conscription under the milder name of "drafting." Taxes had been imposed, debt incurred and paper money issued to the fullest amount possible.
What more could be do but seek refuge in an emancipation proclamation?
On two occasions, within a few weeks before, he had refused to adopt such a measure; but at length he gave way, and on the 22d September --two days before the meeting of the Governors at Altoona — he proclaimed the most atrocious act of war policy which has ever been adopted by a civilized State--adding, in his sore bewilderment, the honest (we doubt not) but impious saying, "I can only trust in God have made no mistake!"

A mistake in what?
Only nine days previously he had stated to a deputation from Chicago his objection to issue a proclamation of emancipation, on the ground "that the whole world would see it to be necessarily as inoperative as the Pope's bull against a comet" In now issuing it, is the mistake which he dreads that the proclamation be too effective in rousing the slaves against their masters, or not effective enough.
With every desire to do justice to Mr. Lincoln as an honest out weak man, in very trying circumstances, we must believe that his only apprehension as to the effect of his proclamation is not in regard to the awful horrors which is may occasion, but lost after all it should fall in accomplishing the conquest of the South.
He said himself not long ago--"I will proclaim emancipation entirely or partially, or not at ad according to of these measures shall seem to me best for the Union" Mr. Seward, in his dispatch to foreign Governments, takes the same view of the matter.
He upholds the President's proclamation as "a just and proper military act,"--adding with an effrontery, partly American that he does not doubt that it will be recognized as such by "all the good and wise men of all counties!" We are greatly mistaken in Earl Russell if he allows Mr. Seward to continue in that convenient belief and if he does not express, in strong arms, the reprobation by the British Government of this atrocious attempt to devastate the South by means of a servile war.

In the immediate effects, and so far as regards the position of the President the proclamation has been a success.
The tub has been thrown to the whale.
The Northerners can no longer account for their reverses by impulsing them to the half measures of the Government.
It is extraordinary the amount of ferocity which exists amen the population of the Northern States especially among the Puritans of the New England States.
The clergy, who are entirely dependent on their congregations, show themselves on this, as on former occasions, ready to pander to the worst passions of the people, and even take the lead in expressions of ferocity.
Even in the churches the war fever rages.--"twenty churches of a night," writes Manhattan from New York, "held prayer meetings to get recruits." And what is the language of the clergy on these occasions?
Here is an instance; The Rev. W. J. Sloane, pastor of the Third Reformed Presbyterian church of New York, was reported in the newspapers to have said, in a speech abounding with similar atrocities, "That it was better that the six millions of white men, women, and children of the South should be slaughtered than that slavery should not be extinguished;" and being consured by an editor for expressing such atrocity, Mr. Sloane replied that what he really said was only as follows: "But suppose emancipation should lead to insurrection!
Let this which I by no means admit us for the time granted; then I affirm but it is better for better, that every man, woman, and child in every rebel State should person in one wide spread bloody, and indiscriminate slaughtes; better that the land should be a Sahara; be as when God destroyed the Canaanites, for overthrew Sodom and Gomorrah, than that this rebellion should be successful" Gen. Wadsworth, who has been nominated by the Republicans as a hair candidate for the Governorship of New York, expresses the feeling of his party in notices ferocious terms. "We intend," says he, "to held the country together at whatever coat of life blood, and We will devastate it if necessary, but not survive its dismemberment."

One might well be at a loss to understand the inhuman zeal which gives vent to such sentiments. --The desire to uphold the Union will not explain it. Doubtless every Yankee would prefer to belong to a State which, in his own estimation at least, could "whip all creation. " That is the only condition of existence which a lows of his indulging in the unlimited impudence and braggadocio which have become part of his nature.
But noes thy one who know the Yankees imagine that they would sacrifice millions and millions of dollars for the sake of upholding an abstract advantage such as the Union?
They do not care a straw for the Constitution, they have sacrificed both legality and liberty long ago, and without a murmur.
Just as little do they care for the Union as a mere political arrangement.
But the Union means far more than this.
At first it meant a continued monopoly of the trade of the South; now it means the very existence of the North itself.
It is an utter mistake to think that it is the South alone which is fighting for existence.
The North is new in the same predicament.
I was not so at first, but it has drifted into that position by the gradual operation of its own acts.
First of all, and as at the outlet, if separation takes place, New York will cease to be the entrepot of the Southern trade.
The "Empire City," which has grown fat on that trade, will dwindle — will become stationary or actually decline; while Charleston, Mobile, and New Orleans will go ahead.

The first act of barbarista, the choking up the harbor of Charleston with stone-laden vessels, showed the bitter jealousy of the New Yorkers; and their desire to obliterate the very existence of a rival port in the South.
New York must come down from its high place; half of its merchants will be beggars if the South takes its trade in its own keeping.
And what is New York, whose fall is thus threatened?
It is the very heart of the North; it is the centre of its resources, the seat of nearly all the available wealth and ready money.
It is the bankers and merchants who take the State loans; but for them Mr. Chase might up his office to-morrow.
And who but they have been foremost in equipping regiments and offering bounties?
Patriots?--they are but worshippers of the almighty dollar." They give their money lavishly, in order that they may retain the source from which their money comes.
They do not desire emancipation, nor a servile war; for the means the ruin of their customers; but some of them assent to the proclamation, in the tops that it may force the South into submission and others, because if the South is to go free and if Southern trade is to seek other channels they will rather see the South a desert than other cities rising into rivalry with New York with the gains which formerly poured into Yankee pockets.

This motive sufficiently explains the vehemence of New York against the project of secession — But there are other reasons, of wider influence which the North your the North has taken up a amount of debt nearly equal to half of the National Debt of Great Britain; and every new expedition or campaign adds to the already enormous amount.
If the South gets off the North will be left to bear the whole burden of the debt which it has incurred.
Doubtless it has hitherto consoled itself, while contracting the debt, with the belief that the conquered South would have to bear its proportion of the burden; and now, when the South seems in a fair way of establishing its independence, the Northerners become absolutely frantic at the prospect before them.
Who is to pay the debt?
Who is to become responsible in cash for the enormous issues of paper money?--The debt ailing from this war will of itself suffice to capture the Union.
Not only does it constitute an additional motive for the obstinate resolve of the South to separate, but it cannot fall to produce still further secession from the Union among the Northern States themselves.
Repudiation is not an unknown proceeding in America, and he is a sanguine man who thinks it will not be had recourse to in regard to this great war debt.
Nearly all the capitalists are to be found in New York Boston, and Philadelphia; and almost all the debt is held by a few of the Atlantic States.
The great agricultural States of the West have hardly contributed a dollar, for they have no accumulated capital.
When this war ends, therefore — as end it must some time — with the South free, and the North burdened with a debt still greater — it may be even double what it is now — the difficulties of the position will only be beginning.
The question of customs duties also will spring up to complete the dissensions which the pressure of the debt will have began.
In the first place, it will be well nigh impossible for the North to maintain its present high tariff.
We hardly anticipate that the South, whatever its desire may be, will be able to start at once on the principles of free trade — for its debt will at first lie heavy on it also.
But we may say to a certainly that it will establish a tariff much below the duties which it suits the interests of the Northeastern States to place upon foreign manufactures; and a thousand custom house and an army of tax-gatherers would not suffice to prevent these lower taxed goods from finding their way across the border into the Northern States in the event of the South accomplishing its independence, the North would be left in every way between the horns of a dilemma.
If it seeks to maintain its high tariff not only will extensive snuggling take place from the South but the agricultural States of the Northwest, who have everything to gain from free trade, will break off and come to a friendly understanding with the South.--On the other hand, if the North abandon its high customs duties how is the interest of the debt to be paid, except by direct taxes, which would equally drive the Western States into repudiation and secession?. In truth, the States of the Northwest have nothing whatever to gain by continuing the war against the South.
The war goes on entirely for, the interests of the Atlantic States to which those of the Northwest are essentially antagonistic.
On the other hand, there is perfect accord between the material interests of the Northwest and the South; and we are surprised that an earnest attempt should not be made by those two parties to come to a pacific settlement.
And such a settlements between the South and the Northwest would perforce end the conflict.

Extreme views, based on the considerations of self in , which we have just described, unquestionably preponderate in the North.
And, as usual, in republican America the tyranny of the majority a lows little scope for the expression of opposite opinions.
Nevertheless there is a section or a party in the North who are opposed to abolitionists, and the other extreme measures which find favor with the Government and the majority of the people.
The small minority of which we speak cannot be spoken of as he Democratic party; for the old Democratic party has almost disappeared; and under the pressure of the times, the mass of it cannot either in action or in speech, be discriminated from the majority, who clamor for extreme measures.
But it consists of Democrats whose aid is now strengthened in their extreme by the concurrence of self interest.
The party is not entirely confined to New York, but it is only in that city that it as yet gives proof of its vitality.
The views of this party are in favor of the prosecution of the war, but they are opposed to any measures calculated to destroy the productiveness of the South or to exasperate the tend beyond all hope of ultimate reconciliation.
They are madly in favor of the Union, but they will accept the Union or rather re-union, upon any terms.
If they cannot conquer the South, they are quite willing that the South should conquer them.
Only give them back the Union, in order that New York may still be the emporiums of the South.
They have thereto clung to the belief that, even though the South triumph there would be no separation.
With an eye to such an issue, they were willing to recognize slavery, and enact fugitive slave laws more stringent thanever.
But the President's proclamation of emancipation has will nigh demolished their house, by embittering the contest beyond the possibility of reconciliation, and also by rendering impossible, on the part of the Norths, concessions to the South, without which there can be no re-union.

The Democratic party have chosen as their candidate democratic deymous, a gentleman of good name and talents, and well qualified to unite his party.
His speech at Albany is by far the boldest and like expression of opinion that has been heard in the North since the commencement of the war. He spoke strongly against the despotic regime under which the country had allowed itself to said and denounced the President's proclamation of emancipation as an act of unparalleled atrocity.
After sarcastically exposing the byposrisy of the Abolitionists among whom the President must now be Yankee--who, while the South holds that the negroe is fit to live in America as a slave, deny that he is fine to live in America at all, and insist on his betaking himself to Liberia or the coalpits of Panama--Mr. Seymour thus spoke of the President's proclamation.

Such malignity and cowardice would invoke the interference of civilized Europe.
History tells of the files kindled in the name of religion, of atrocities committed under the pretexts of order or liberty, it is now urged that scenes bloodies than the world has not witnessed shall be enacted in the name of philant reply.

Although the Democratic party--who may be described as opposed to abolition and all extreme measures has given little sign of existence since the war began, and although, under the regime of martial law which has now been proclaimed for the whole Northern States it will encounter, perhaps, insuperable obstacles to its action it must be borne in mind that whether nominally belonging to it or not, some of the ablest and most powerful men in the State share his opinions in regard to the conduct of the war.

But if they carry the day it will facilitate the accomplishment of one strange event more which looniz amongst the possibilities of the future.
In order to propitiate the South, and retain its old commercial pre-eminence, it is not improbable that, amongst the troubles consequent upon this war, we may see New York set up "on its own hock," and declare itself a free city — a Hamburg of the West--disowning all allegiance, repudiating all antipathy, and establishing it. If at an independent power on "purely commercial principle!"

In a moral point of view there cannot be but two opinions in this country as to the President's proclamation.
To amploy such a means of hostility as a negro insurrection is simply infamous.
In a political point of view, we regard it as the greatest mistake which the North has committed.
True, the policy of the North has been slowly approximating to this result; it is a natural climax to the mad policy which has animated the North from the beginning.
It is the consummation of the mistakes of the North.
Union in any shape is now doubly impossible.
It remains to be seen, also, whether the temporary accord which the proclamation has established in the North is not on the surface only, and whether the present full of dissension will not give way ere long to dissensions, still more formidable.
In the border States of Kentucky, Tennessee, and Missouri, the proclamation cannot fall to excite new and formidable opposition to the Federal Government; while the Confederate States, now menaced with untold horrors, will put forth their whole strength to keep the danger at a distance, and to roll back the war from their frontiers with the fury of desperation.

"All the good and wise men of all countries"--to use Mr. Seward's phrase — far from approving the proclamation of the President as "a just and proper military act," will see in it a new reason for desiring a prompt termination of this deplorable, insane, and fratricidal contest.
The question will now be asked louder than ever, "Is no one to interfere?
Is the horrible contest to be allowed to go on till it end in horrors still greater?" In regard to the question of recognizing the South we need have no hesitation in proclaiming Sir. G. C. Lewil's statement of the import of international law to be the most erroneous and ridiculous statement ever hazarded by a Minister of the Crown — Passing over the manifest absurdities of the way in which he expresses his opinion, and looking only at the substantial averment that no recognition of a new State can rightfully take place until the war is either formally or virtually at an end, we find the averment contradicted by the circumstances which have attended every recognition of a new State by this country since the century begin.
We hastened to recognize the Spanish republics of South America while they were still engaged in a war with the parent State, and it was a band of British legionaries who turned the tide of battle in the action which finally crushed the hopes of Spain.
Greece, also, we recognized while that country was still struggling with the power of the Turks indeed, we intervened for the express purpose of preventing the Turks re- establishing their power over the rebellious province.
Belgium was a still stronger instance; for in that care, but for the military intervention of France and England, the Dutch would very soon have given a good account of the braves belges. And in the recent case of Naples old we not recognize its annexation to Piedmont, while the King and his army still held their ground in his old dominions?
So far, therefore and is a question of legality, England would be amply justified in recognizing the independence of the Confederate States.

As a question of policy however the matter is not so easily decided.
For England singly to give a formal recognition of the South as an independent State, without taking any steps to put an end to the war, would be of very little benefit to the South and, as a measure of humanity, would be of whatever.
At the same time it would give great offence to the North, thus making an enemy, without gaining a friend.
But the case would be far otherwise if our Government were to act in this instance in the same manner as they did in the case of Greece and Belgium--that is to ray, if they were to resolve not only to recognize the independence of the South, but to support that independence by a demonstration of force.
The case has now become most urgent; for not only does international law justify our recognition of the Southern Confederacy, but humanity demands that we should take measures to put an end to so horrible a war. No doubt it would be a delicate matter, and a matter also of doubtful policy for England, to intervene alone.
But intervention of some kind is now urgently demanded.
And if the Great Powers of Europe — or at least England, Russia, and France--would solve the difficulty which each power separately feels, by agreeing to undertake a joint mediation, and, if necessary, intervention, they would render an important service to civilization humanity, and mankind at large, and would show a better example of a "Holy Alliance" than any which yet stands recorded in the pages of history.

div3.head: Military Execution.

dateline.name: Headq's 1st Brigade Light Division, Camp Gregg, near Fredericksburg,

div3.p:
Private Patrick McGee, Company B, 40th Va. Regiment was executed to-day.
The accused was convicted by a general Court-martial of perjury, desertion, and robbery.
He perjured himself by swearing that be was a foreigner, and not a member of any military company, being at the time a deserter from Company 1, 1st Va. Regiment.
He twice became substitute, and as often deserted.
The Court sentenced him "to be shot to death with musketry."

This morning that sentence was duly executed, in the presence of the brigade, the command being given by Lieut. Dorsey Ficklin.
Obeight balls, five pierced his body.
He died without a groan.--McGee showed no signs of fear at his a worsening doom.
He said he was not afraid to die. His wife and a priest had been telegraphed for but did not arrive in time to console his few remaining hours.
Let deserters and substitutes take warning.

div3.head: Arrest of a Yankee deserter and supposed spy.
div3.p:
--On Saturday last a man named Albert W. Sinclair; who also passes under the alias of Carrington, was arrested on 31 street in the neighborhood of the African Church, by Detective Fred Shaffer, of the Eastern District, in the same tenement from which Webster the spy. was taken.
About nine months since Sinclair, who at that time passed for a Lieutenant in the Yankee army, and professed to be a deserter, appeared in Richmond, and was committed to Castle Godwin as a spy. After being there a considerable time he succeeded in purloining himself on a green sentinel as an officer of the prison, and not only liberated himself but passed out on his own authority the notorious Colonel Adler, a fellow-prisoner, who succeeded in making his way to the North--The officers had nothing of Sinclair's whereabouts until a few days ago, when they were privately informed that he was in the city, and took measures to effect his arrest, in which they were successful, as above related.
It is believed that he has been backwards and forwards from this city to the North several times since he escaped, and been thus useful to the enemy as a spy. When near the corner of 5th and Broad streets, on his way to prison, he broke from the officers and fled precipitately up Broad till arriving at 2d street, down which he retreated rapidly till near the Alms-House, when he was headed off and again taken in custody.
While the fugitive was attempting to escape three shots were fired at him, but without effect.
He was taken to Castle Thunder for trial before Court Martial.

div3.head: Descent on a Sporting House.
div3.p:
--The neighborhood of north Main street, near the corner of 12th, was thrown into commotion about 5 o'clock on Saturday evening by the appearance of a detachment of the city police, who proceeded immediately to make a descent on certain rooms in that vicinity used as a place for unlawful gaming.
The following parties found in the house were taken to the cage, viz: Dick Copeland, J. A. Levy, Stephen Burress, Henry Beardsley, B. F. Dunnavan, Charles Eives, Andrew Zell, David B. Cox, Benj.
deGroot, Wm. D. Allen, Jecome Diggs, Richard Puryear, M. T. Yates, E. M. Ezekiel, Alex'r Zol'man, F. H. Pendleton.
Charles Wilson, John Burchar, and Nicholas Manly.
The charge Against Copeland was, keeping and exhibiting the game called Erro; the others were arrested for being present at the same.
After being carried to the cage, all were released on giving $200 bail each to appear before the Mayor this morning.
Sundry Faro tables a half bushel of ivory chips, and other gambling apparatus were seized, put in an ambulance by the police, and carted off to the cage.

div3.head: Prison Items.
div3.p: --The following arrivals have been chronicled at Castle Thunder since Saturday; James Cline, company E, 57th S. C., desertion; Andrew Rogers alias Major Manning, A. Marar alias Lieutenant Robert Lynne, and George Carvener, for engaging in the substitute business as officers and agents; also, William Bushel a substitute; John Henry, slave of Jesse Williams, was rent in by Major Peyton Wise having been arrested while trying to get to the Yankee; Charles, slave of Timothy Eider, was arrested as a deserter from the fortification; Patrick Haggerty was sent from the naval hospital for drunkenness.

A men named Yarrington, a supposed spy, was taken in custody at the house of Wm. Betchtell, on 3d, between Marshall and Clay streets and lodged in the prison for examination by the military authorities.
The detectives also carried to the prison yesterday.
Capt. George Hedler, of company I, 5th Louisiana, who was taken in custody for being a substitute agent.
Seventeen hundred dollars, paid by parties for substitutes to this person, was recovered from him.

div3.head: Obsequies of Major C. R. Wheat.
div3.p: --The funeral of this well known and gallant officer, who was killed at the battle of Mechanicsville, before Richmond, in July last while leacing his command into action, took place in this city on Saturday last, from the Monumental Church, on Broad street.

A large concourse of military and citizens, plentifully interspersed with ladies, assembled at the church at an early hour to hear the funeral sermon, which was delivered by the Rev. J. C. McCabe, after which the coffin, containing the remains of the distinguished dead, was removed from the church to a caisson, drawn by four span of horses, which had been appropriately selected to convey it to Hollywood Cemetery.
The line of procession was then formed, as follows: City Battalion, Major Elliott commanding; Public Guard, Lieut. Gay commanding detachment of the Tiger Rifles; two bands or music; caisson, containing the coffin; after which followed Louisiana officers now in the city, Gen. Elzey and Staff, Gen. Henningsen, and officers of the army, citizens, &c., and the cortege closed with carriages containing friends and acquaintances of the deceased.

Major Chatham Roburdean Wheat was a native of Alexandrie, Va., and was distinguished not only for his fine personal appearance, but for those qualities which constitute a gallant officer and true gentleman.
Of a restless, roving and chivalrous disposition, the Mexican war first opened a path for his peculiar genius, since when his sword has not in its scaboard, but wherever struggling liberty needed a champica, whether it was upon the battle- fields of Mexico, Nica agus, Italy, or his own native South, he was among the first to respond to the call.
Major Wheat wished to die, amidst the flashing of the guns, and with the flag of his country waving victoriously above him.

div3.head: The Abolition prisoners.
div3.p:
--Owing to the fact that no boat was reported at City Point on Saturday or Sunday, none of the Abolition prisoners left by flag of truce on those days.
They will be started off directly the Lincoln Government provides a conveyance for them. "Saturday evening thirty-two Yankees were brought to the Libby prison, twenty-four of whom came from Tennessee, the balance were captured near Manassas, and were brought down by the Central railroad.

Note.--Sunday evening the telegraph reported the arrival of four steamboats at City Point, and last night eighteen hundred Yankees were gotten ready for a journey this morning.
We believe the Yankee boats brought few, if any, passengers bound South.
They will carry the Yankees to the camp for paroled men near Annapolis, Md., where a large number will embrace the opportunity of running off, as they have done heretofore.

div3.head: Reprieves, pardons, &c
div3.p:
--By a communication relative to pardons, reprieves, &c., of Penitentiary convicts, up to January, 1863, made by Governor Letcher to the General Assembly on Saturday, it appears that since December 4th, 1861, forty eight residents of the Penitentiary have been pardoned, and one (a slave) reprieved from hanging.
In most cases the parties who received Executive clemency had not only conducted themselves well while prisoners, but had served out most of their terms.
The Governor says that since the date above mentioned no case has occurred where he has thought it expedient or right to commute capital punishment.*

div3.head: Acquitted.
div3.p: --Hugh Reagan, who was charged with stealing two horses, was examined before Justice Nettles, of Henrico, last week, and honorably discharged — witnesses proving that he had purchased the two horses for $100 from John D. Graves, and the bill of sale for the same being exhibited.--Graves was sent on for trial at the County Court.

div3.head: To be shot.
div3.p:
--John Mulligan, of company F, 5th Virginia cavalry, who was condemned to be shot for desertion, will be duly executed to-day, unless the Secretary of War should respite him, which has been done twice before for periods of twenty days each.
The last respite expires to-day, and so will Mulligan, unless the Secretary should renew his term of existence.

div3.head: Court proceedings.
div3.p:
--Mary Vanderlip was arraigned on the charge of shooting a pistol at the person of Owen Riley, on Broad street, Friday.
The defendant is the wife of Piles Vanderlip, now in the City Jail on a conviction for misdemeanor, and attends, during his absence to an oyster saloon near 2d and Broad streets of which they are joint proprietors.
The dispute which ceased her to resolve to take summary vengeance on Elley originated in the saloon shout some tariffing matter which the Mayor thought hardly sufficient to warrant the sought to be obtained.
Mrs. Vanderlip required to give security for her good behaviors.

Luke Kellogg was charged with committing larceny in refraining possession of a lot of personal property belonging to Lexster Jones.
It was established, in this case to the faction first, that no larceny had been committee second, that if a larceny had been committee defendant knew nothing about it third, that the articles claimed to have been stolen had been put in possession of the wife of the accused for safe keeping.
The case was dismissed and defend at discharged from custody.

Several slaves, who had ventured to wander about the streets without permission were ricked up by the watch and arraigned before his Honor, who ordered each of them a whipping.
Twenty odd servants, of various kinds found in an unlawful assembly in the kitchen of Mr. W. Willis, were also brought up and ordered a suitable whipping.
The darkips were, as usual, indulging in the delights of a "party," when the watchmen unceremoniously ventured and carried them off to the cage, not giving them time to devour the edibles fixed up for the occasion.

David Jones, who works at the Tredogar foundry, was summoned up at the instance of Samuel Maguire, who charged him with being the owner of a vicious dog that, on last Wednesday night, had bitten him without provocation, while peaceably pursuing his way along one of the public streets of the city.
Mr. Jones was fined $5 for all, wing his dog to get into the street, and an order was entered condemning the brute to be summarily disposed of if it was not removed from the city immediately.

Byrd M. Welsh was arraigned for going into the Columbian Hotel and stealing two pairs of blankets, worth $30, from Chas. W. Spicar, the proprietor.
The proof sustaining the charge.
Welsh was committed for further examination before the Hustings Court.

Chase, Hampton, Theodore Eacho, and Jesse Clark, three boys, employed as teamsters by the C. S. army, having come to Richmond on army mules, on a frolic, were arrested by the Provost Guard and sent before the Mayor by Major Grawold.--The Mayor said the parties had committed a trespass only by law, and decided that they should be carried back to Major Griswold.
They were discharged by the latter.

Habeas Corpus.--Theodore Whitman one of the parties arrested for selling liquor in violation of the proclamation of martial law forbidding its safe, was before Judge Lyons, of the Hustings Court, on Saturday, on a habeas corpus, in order to test the right of the military authorities to hold him for trial before the Court Martial for the offences charged against him. Mr. Wm. W. Crump appeared in support of the petitioner, and adduced a number of authorities to show that the military authorities had no right to arrest and try Whitman, he not being a soldier, and therefore not amenable to military law. The argument was replied to by Mr. Robert Ould in behalf of the Government — The case is still under advisement, but a decision will be had in a few days.

div3.head:
Later from the North.
Inauguration of Gov. Parker of New Jersey.
advance in Cotton, &c.
div3.p:
--The New York Herald, of the 21st has been received here.
The first page contains full details of the capture of Arkansas Poss, confirming previous accounts by telegraph.
Colonel John W. Dunnington, of Ky., commanded the Confederates.

Senator Wall, of N. J. was the Girard House on the night of the 19th inst., He made a speech, compiling the Union to a ship at sea in distress, with an incompetent pilot at the helm.--It would never be able to ride the storm bill a Democrat took his place.
The crowd groaned at the mention of the names of Lincoln and Hutler, and cheered KcCiel an. The proceedings were attuned with considerable excitement.

Governor Parker, of New Jersey, was inaugurated at Trouton on the 20th inst., The city was crowded with people from all parts of the State.
There was a grand military parade, and great enthusiasm prevailed.

Governor Parker, in his inaugural, denounced the assumptions of the Federal Government, and repudiated the emancipation proclamation.
He closed by asking if there is no way, con with the honor and interests of all, to bring to an end this unnatural strife, which is shedding the best blood of the land and eating out our substance?

There is not a good citizen in the whole country who does not in his heart desire peace.
There is not a Christian family in the land who, when the shades of evening close around, do not, in their devotion at the family altar pray for peace and the safe and speedy return of the long absent one.--There is not a soldier in the Northern or Southern armies who, as he paces at night his weary round, or lays his head upon the rude camp pillow, does not in imagination visit the fireside at home and sigh for peace.

We should not be afraid of peace — an honorable and permanent peace — whether it come by the exercise of power or by the exercise of conciliation.
It should be a peace on the basis of "the Union as it was"--not a Union of States where part are held in subjugation as conquered provinces, adding nothing to the material interests and prosperity of the nation, and only furnishing a theatre of action for swarms of military officials — but a Union of all the States, with their "equality and rights unimpaired."

It should be a peace founded on the submission of all to the rightful authority of the Government, and the guarantee to all of their constitutional rights by the Government.
It should be a peace bringing with it such unity as will have the Constitution for its foundation and obedience to law its corner stone.
The Governor was frequently enthusiastically applauded during the delivery of his address.

Eighty four members of the Missouri Legislature met at Jefferson City, and adopted a memorial to President Lincoln, setting forth that there is still underlying the surface of the State a very large substratum of treasonable sentiment, which may break out at the first favorable opportunity, and urging Lincoln to use his utmost caution in rescinding or modifying orders that have coercive influence on the country's enemies.
Cotton has advanced — middlings closing at 75½@76½ etc. Gold closed at 147½ bid. Exchange 163.

div3.head:
Still later from the North.
address from Burnside to his troops.

argument.p: Another "On to Richmond" movement — the Rappahannock crossed — Misgivings of the officers, &c., &c.

div4.p: --I have just received from City Point, by flag of truce train, a copy of the N. Y. Tribune, of Friday, 23d inst.:
Burnside has issued the following address to his troops dated Headquarters Army of the Potomac, near Falmouth, Jan. 23.:
General Orders, No. 7.--The Commanding General announces to the Army of the Potomac that they are about to meet the enemy once more.

The late brilliant actions in North Carolina, Tennessee, and Arkansas, have divided and weakened the enemy on the Rappahannock, and the suspicious moment seems to have arrived to strike a great and mortal blow to the rebellion and to gain that decisive victory which is due to the country.
Let the gallant soldiers of so many brilliant battle fields accomplish this achievement, and a fame the most glorious await them.

The Commanding General calls for the firm and united action of officers and men, and under the Prevalence of God, the Army of the Potomac will have taken the great step toward restoring peace to the country and the Government to its rightful authority.
By command of

The Tribune's correspondent, six miles above Falmouth, Jan. 20, writes: All, day, and late into night, artillery has been rolling and rumbling forward, and all the highways and by-ways have been rendered useful in hurrying rapidly onward the forces destined for striking the "great and mortal blow, " which General Burnside truly says "is due to the country." Many thousand troops are new concentrated at the point where Gen. Burnside having seized upon the diversion of the enemy to another quarter, has determined to push his army across the Rappahannock and attack the enemy in rear of their fortifications at Fredericksburg.

The result is now trembling in the balance.
The Simely arrival of the pontoons, with the friendly co-operation of all the other elements which are involved in the issue, we trust, will bring us a decisive victory.
But the present situation fills us with apprehensions for the morrow.
The pontoons, already due, have not yet arrived, and a cold and pelting rain storm excites the fear that destiny is not in our favor.
Great chances are to be tried to-morrow, and we await the issue with the greatest solicitude.

The movement which is now in progress was ordered to commence on Sunday morning. It was postponed for some reason until Monday.
On Monday it was again postponed until Tuesday, when at 9 o'clock A. M. Franklin's grand division, the 6th army corps (Gen. Smith) in the advance, commenced moving from their position, five miles below Falmouth, towards Gen. Burnside's headquarters.

Hooker's centre grand division commenced its march at 11 A. M., and being nearer the destination of its movement, proceeded Franklin toward Banks's Ford.
To make the advance, those roads were used which were sufficiently back from the river to prevent the enemy from observing it.--The Warrenton turnpike was accordingly reached, not by the direct route through Falmouth, but by way of Stoneman's Station, and roads which had been prepared by the difficult labor of the Pioneer corps.

The circular of Gen. Burnside has been read to the entire army.
The army has received it as a pledge of success.
The men have not received its gratulatory allusions to the recent victories in North Carolina, Tennessee, and Arkansas, with a inquiries about failure at Vicksburg, or the loss of cannon at Murfreesboro', but rejoiced to take courage from its inspiring utterances, and have faith in the triumphant issue of the impending movement.
Whatever the issue, it will not prove disastrous because the men have not fought well enough.

Preparations for the movement have been most careful and thorough.
Roads have been built to a dozen places on the river, that the enemy, threatened at various points, might thereby be left in perplexity in regard to our intentions, and that a favorable diversion in any direction might be immediately turned to advantage by crossing rapidly at a point distant from where the enemy had concentrated.
Every point of the river has been carefully examined, and the possibility of protecting a crossing with the artillery been fully studied.--The fullest military maps have been elaborated, and guides have been instructed and rendered familiar with the numerous roads and by ways necessary for the rapid concentration of the army.
The locality chosen for the construction of the bridges and the crossing of the army is six miles from Falmouth.

Since writing the above it is learned that the head of the bridge train has arrived to within half a mile of the river.
The storm is raging with incrossing severity, which, however intolerable it may be to the soldiers who are sitting and slavering around their bivouac fires, will prove a valuable cover to the secrecy of the bridge building.

Should fortune smile favorable upon our undertaking during the next twelve hours we hope to have driven the enemy before us and have gained the rear of Fredericksburg.
Then it is experted that Sumner's Grand Division will cross the Rappahannock near Falmouth.
Then will follow the building of the railroad bridge across the Rappahannock.
Timbers are all ready, every beam unit plank, and they will be thrown together with the greatest rapidity, and communication extended by rail with our supplies.

No demonstration has occurred upon the picket lines — now after midnight. All is quiet as would upon the other side of the river.
But while the enemy can hardly have failed to observe the bivouac fires of our forces which have appeared to night in such unusual numbers, the wind, which is blowing strongly from their position, will carry no noise of the artillery wagons or the bridge train.
Another letter, dated "Opposits Fredericksburg, Tuesday, January 20, 6 P. M.," says:

q.p:
The movement has at last commenced.
At 11 A. M. to-day the reserve artillery and infantry division, of Hocker's command, the railroad at Stoneman's Station and moved, Harwood Church, up the Rappahannock, by a road three miles back of it, and of course from the rebel camps and pickets on the south side of the river.
Two hours later the remainder of Hooker's grand division took the road.

div4.p:
Franklin's grand division, like Hooker's is heavy matching, also started at 12 o'clock, moving in the same direction, though by a rests nearer; the river.
Some of his stragglers, his baggage and ammunition trains, were visible from the rebel camps, which, for some purpose, most have been done intentionally.

There has been very unusual reticence in reports to this movement.
Up to this time even the camp commanders do not know the plan which seems to be confined to Burnside and his Grand Division Generals.
It is gratifying to know that such a secret can be kept in the army.

An unusually serious feeling pervades the officers of the army.
It is fell to be a very critical period.
The tone of the troops has been despondent for the last two weeks, and another decided repulse would bring results unpleasant to contemplate.
I believe the troops will do their duty, but without any of the run and animation which springs from enthusiasm. "We have enough men to succeed," remarked Gen. Hocker to-day; "if our force cannot, five millions could not." The army is doubtless strong enough in more numbers.
God grant that it may be strong enough in spirit and confidence.

div4.head: Latest — the Rappahannock crossed.
div4.p: --The Washington Star, of yesterday afternoon, is received. --It has the following highly important intelligence in regard to the movements of the army under command of Major General Burnside:

The understanding in Washington to-day is, that a portion of the Army of the Potomac, General Hooker's division, has at last certainly crossed the Rappahannock, and that the movement took place yesterday.
Mr. Denning, principal agent of the Associated Press with the army of the Potomac, and his assistant, Theodore Barnard, have been arrested and sent away from camp.

The Weehawken arrived at Hampton Roads Thursday, three days from New York, having ridden out one of the most terrific gales experienced for months.
When off the Delaware breakwater the tug which had the Weehawken in tow, frightened by the coming gale, put in, but Captain Rodgers stood on his course, saying he wanted to see what stuff his vessel was made of. The storm of Tuesday was a hurricane.
The waves ran 33 feet high, and rolled over the deck.
A little water leaked in at some of the port holes, and there was a slight leakage forward, but no damage was done and no repairs are required.
Nothing has yet been heard from the Nahant, but the Department is persuaded of her safety.
The money to pay the armies of Rosecrane and Grant has been furnished, and the greater part of the funds to pay the soldiers in North Carolina and the Department of the South has also been issued.
B. F. Wade was elected to the United States Senate from Ohio, on Thursday, by a majority of 24.

Cairo, Jan. 21.--The gunboat Lexington has just arrived, convoying 4,796 rebel prisoners of war from the Post of Arkansas.
After the capture of the place Gen. McClelland hastened off for Little Rock, and expected to surprise and capture it. The expedition has not been heard from.
No Speaker had been elected at Albany at best accounts.

The American House at Niagara Falls was burned last week.
Ralph Waido Emerson made his through smoke and flame.

Gold in New York Thursday, 147½.
Exchange 162½@163½.

Capt. Coombs, of the steamer Tric, reached Louisville on the 12th instant.
He confirms the instruction of his own and two other transports on the Cumberland river by rebel cavalry.
He says that the gunboat Slidell surrendered without firing a gun.

Gen. Fitz John Porter was found guilty on all the charges preferred against him, and dishonorably dismissed.
The finding was approved by President Lincoln.

div3.head: Later from Europe.
div3.p: --The Herald contains news from Europe to the 11th instant, by the Arabia, at Halifax.
Rumors of mediation in the war affairs of America, on the part of Napoleon, were again in Paris.
It was said, that the news of the defeat of the Union troops at Fredericksburg had again turned his Majority's attention seriously towards that line of policy.

Hon. Mr. Dayton, United States Minister in Paris, had an audiences of the Emperor on New Year's day, a conference with N. Drouys &L'Huys, Minister of Foreign Affairs, on the instant, and another audience with the Emperor on the 7th inst.,
It was said that the Emperor recommended an armistice between the North and South to Mr. Dayton.

The Paris correspondent of the London Times says that steps have been, or will be, immediately taken to renew the peace overtures already made unsuccessfully to President Lincoln, and "this time it is hoped with a prospect of better success."
The British Government still persevered in its refusal to interfere in the American war in any form.
Meetings in support of the Union had been held in different parts of England.
The Emancipation Society of London had voted an address to Mr. Lincoln, which was committed to the care of Mr. Adams, U. S., Minister, for transmission.

The Liverpool Chamber of Commerce had arranged for affording a suitable reception to the officers of the first ship arriving from America with previsions for the relief of the distressed operatives of Lancashire.

Most of the London journals condemn the London Times for its open attempt to justify slavery on Scriptural grounds.
It was thought that a great reaction against the influence of the London Times would, ensue.

The opposition party in the Spanish consured the Cabinet for withdrawing from the Mexican alliance with France, the members asserting that England only gained by such a course.
Chicago said that Spain should support the candidature of a Spanish Prince for the throne of Mexico.
Another brigade of French troops was under orders for Mexico.
The Emperor had directed an inquiry to be made as to the actual condition of the distressed cotton operatives of France.
The United States steamer T near the late privateer Sumter at on the 31st of December.

div3.head: The intercepted dispatches.
div3.p:
The affair of the intercepted dispatches seems to have excited in a very transient manner the public mind.
The sensation it produced hardly survived twenty-four hours. The general conclusion arrived at appears to be that the disclosures they make are not very important, and little injury, if any, it likely to ensue to the Confederate States.

On two points, with reference to the matter there is one unanimous sentiment.
First.
That Mr. Benjamin's speculations about the motives of Louis Napoleon were entirely out of place prior to the settlement of the question whether the acts of the French agents in Texas were authorized by him or not. Second.
That the interception of the dispatches is very strange.
How could it happen?
It is the general custom to take precautions to prevent the enemy from getting important papers in transits upon the seas — such precautions, intend, as are certain.
How, than, were they seized?
How was it that the simple means usually employed were not resorted to do prevent this?
This is a matter, of course, for the Government to look into, and the event is one of those expensive lessons of experience which should be turned to account in future.

div3.head: Reconstruction.
div3.p:
Nothing falls more strangely on Southern ears than the talk of reconstruction which we hear so much of in the resolutions and speeches of Northern Conservatives.
How to underelys men who indulge such illusions we know not. They must put themselves in our places, undergo all that we have undergone and feel all that we feel, in order to understand that, of all impossible things in this world, the reconstruction of the old Union is the most impossible.
Reconstruction! Can they reconstruct the family circles which they have broken — can they reconstruct the fortunes which they have scattered — can they reconstruct the bodies of our dead kindred, which by tens of thousands they have destroyed!
When they can do this, they can reconstruct the old Union.
When they can do this, when they can breathe the breath of life into the pallid facts of our sons and brothers, and restore them once more, living and happy, to our desolate firesides, they may dream of bringing back that Union whose only principles of cohesion was the mutual love and confidence of its people.

We can comprehend the logic of the brutal Republicans when they scoff at the idea of rebuilding the old Union upon the principles of the American Constitution, and hold out before us only subjugation or extermination.
With all their demoniac ferocity, they have at least the sense to understand that they have sinned past forgiveness, and that they have nothing to expect of a people whom they have so outraged, but the most inextinguishable hate.
They know and feel in their inmost souls that they and we can only be united again as master and slave, and slaves they mean to make us, if brute and bloody force can ever accomplish that object.
We despise their threats, but acknowledge that there is but one road to the re-union of America under one Government, and that is over the dead bodies of every man, woman, and child in the Southern Confederacy.
They will never be our masters, and we would not have them for our slaves.
Death must come in one form or another to us all, and in none could it come more glorious and honorable than in defence of the inalienable rights of man. Better death in any form than submission to the brutal despotism which for two long years has bathed its hand in the heart's blood of our best and bravest, and which gives us no alternative but to kiss the steel that is red with our kindred blood or perish.

We warn the Democrats and Conservatives of the North is dismiss from their minds at once the miserable delusion that the South can ever consent to enter again, upon any terms, the old Union.
If the North will allow us to write the Constitution ourselves, and give us every guarantee we would ask, we would sooner be under the Government of England or France, then under a Union with men who have shown that they cannot keep good faith, and are the most barbarous and inhuman, as well as treacherous, of mankind.
Suppose two men engaged in partnership fall out, and one of them, after violating every article of the agreement of partnership, destroyed the property of the other, burns his house over his head, butchers his wife and children, and then asks the other to renew their old partnership and go on in business again as if nothing had happened!
This is a faint image of what the Northern Reconstructionists ask of the South.
If we could agree to it our folly would be only equalled by their villainy.
Loyalty to them is treason to our dead, to ourselves, and to humanity.

If the Reconstructionists want peace, they can easily have it, upon the terms on which they could have always had it — letting us alone.
We ask neither more nor less.
We are making no war on them.--We are not invading their territory, nor giving their homes to the flames, their populations to prison and the sword, their women to a fate worse than death.
Let us alone!
That is all we ask.--Let us alone, and peace will return once more to bless a distracted land.
But do not expect us to degrade ourselves and east dishonor upon the graves of our kindred, by ever returning to the embrace of those whose hands are dripping with the tears and blood of our people.

div3.head: The naval power of the United States.
div3.p:
We have never denied that, whilst the Yankees are rather indifferent soldiers, they make very good sailors.
They have had long training, and have attained great proficiency, in maritime matters.--From the moment when their enterprise in the whale fisheries extorted the eloquent panegyric of Burke to the present day, they have shown unusual aptitude for a sea life.
The fishing bounties, the monopoly of the coasting trade, and the vast carrying trade between America and Europe have given full scope and exposure to their great maritime energies.
If the fanaticism of New England had not overthrown the old Constitution and Government, the United States would have soon be come the first commercial and naval power of the world.
A third war with England, which would have been inevitable would have transferred the undisputed capture of the seas to American bands, and the lapse of another century would have placed the Old World at the feet of the New.

But such seems not to have been the design of Providence.
The nerves and sinews of that maritime power which threatened to overwhelm the earth have been abruptly sundered in the dissolution of the Union.
The land which furnished Yankeedom the great staples of its commerce, which furnished it the fishing bounties that trained its seaman, and even the very live oak, pine, tar, and hemp that equipped its ships, has been lost forever to the United States.
It must hereafter give up its proud ambition of being a first-rate naval and commercial power.
No wonder that it puts forth such gigantic efforts in this war. Those efforts are for self- preservation, over more than for Southern subjugation.
The latter is now sought as a means to an end, and that end is, to keep itself on the map of the world.
It is astonishing that England, which sees and knows there facts, statedly and perseveringly maintain the position of us called neutrality, and deliberately incur the hazard of a restoration of her old rival to the capacity of inflicting upon her at a future period the ruin of her commercial and naval ascendancy.
So soon as the United States triumph in this struggle, which happily is now out of the question — so soon Britancia will cease to rule the waves, and a hundred years ago will become a solitary barren side of the ocean.

div3.head: Married.

div4.head: Obituaries.
div4.p: Killed, on the 14th September, 1862, at the battle of Crampton Gap, Private John E. Collier, of the Richmond Grays, 12th regiment Va. Vols.--He leaves a wife, two small children, and an uncle of friends to mourn their loss.

He was one among the first when this unholy war broke out to go forth to battle for his country's rights.
He participated in the battles of Seven Pines and Chickahominy, and fought with an unflinching spirit.
He was also at the surrender of Harper's Ferry and the battles of Manassas; but the God of battles saw fit to take him from our midst.
He was shot through the hip at Crampton Gap.
After being wounded he took his handkerchief from his pocket and bound up his wound.--He died in about twenty minutes afterwards.
He was a devoted husband and an affectionate father.
He was much beloved by all who knew him.

lg.l: Forget thee, and when life shall cease
To thrill this heart of mine;
But not till then can I forget
One look or tone of thine.

Oh, no!
it mingles with the scuzd
And think ye I can forget.
The one I loved so dear.

Died at Selma, Ala, the residence of their parents, on Monday, December 29th, 1862, Philip Aylett Cabell, aged 14 months; and on Sunday, January 4th, 1863, Mary Hall Cabell aged 2 years and 9 months; and on Thursday, January 8th, 1863, Anna Henry Cabell, aged 4 years and 5 months children of Dr. Patrick Henry and Pattle Waller Cabell, formerly of Virginia.

In less than two weeks after that malignant scourge, scarlet fever, visited the once happy home of these now almost broken-hearted parents, it hushed in the silence of death the sweet voices of all their beautiful and attractive children, and left their bright Southern home almost as dark and joyless as the comb to which their children had been consigned.
Whilst we know that time, the great console, and the lessons of pious resignation, taught by religion, can also lessen the anguish of the bereaved parents of their little angels, it may to some slight extent alleviate their grief to know that their sorrow is shared by a large circle of friends and relatives in their native State.

div4.head: Tributes of respect
div4.p: At a meeting of the member of the "Governor's Mounted Guard," the following preamble and resolutions were unanimously adopted:

We feel it our sad duty to pay some public and formal respect to the memory of our lamented comrade.
Charles L. Deabl who has been suddenly taken away from us by the hand of God.--Taken violently ill of fever in camp the first day of this month, he was sent to the hospital in Richmond on the 3d, under the care of a kind and attentive friend, a member of the company, who remained with him tid his death, and performed his last and duties to his body at the grave on the 8th instant.

A native of Berryville, Clarke co., Va., where his parents now reside he went to South Carolina when that State seceded from the United States, and joined the 1st S. C. volunteers at Sumter, and fought with them at the first battle of Manassas, under the brave Col. Gregg.
After that regiment was disbanded he joined this company in August, 1861, generously substituting himself, without remuneration, for a member of the company whose family misfortunes at that time rendered it necessary for him to leave the service.
Having shared with us the dangers and hardships of war with the spirit of a true soldier, when we say we lament him and miss him at the social mess, it but feebly expresses our sorrow for his untimely loss.
Death was endeared to us by many noble qualities.
He was of an impulsive character, which sometimes perhaps rendered him indirect; but his impulses were always manly and generous.
He was gentlemanly, social kind generous, and brave.
He possessed unusually nice, feelings and the tenderest sympathy for others; and, generous almost to a fault, was ever ready to share what he had with others.
Having been with us in many conflicts with the enemy, we knew him to be brave.
He particularly distinguished himself for personal courage on the 18th of November last, when a portion of our regiment charged a greatly superior force of the enemy's cavalry in the streets of Warrenton, Va., Dashing far ahead of our charging column into the midst of the enemy's advance guard, he wounded one and dispersed the others — He was a true patriot, and we trust his soul is with God!
Therefore, be it.

list.item: 1st. Resolved, That by the death of Chas. L. Deah we have lost one of our warmest and truest friends--one of our best comrades, and one of our bravest soldiers.
2d. Resolved, That we tender to the parents of the deceased our deep sympathies in their bereavement, and hope God will heal the wound he has inflicted on them.
3d. Resolved, That we forward the above preamble and resolutions for publication in the Richmond Dispatch and Examiner.

div3.p: at a meeting of company a, 15th regiment Va. Vols. Convened on the 23d January, 1863, for the purpose of paying the last tribute of respect to 1st Sergeant C. C. Cherry, and Privates Geo W. Brooke, Chas Pkeples, Chas T. Lockett, and Geo W. Otey, who fell while gallantry and nobly discharging their duty in the memorable battle of Sharpsburg, September 17th 1862, the following preamble and resolutions were adopted:

Whereas, it hath pleased Almighty God to remove from our midst some of our most valuable and useful members, C. C. Charry, George W. Brooke, Chas. P. Kepler, Chas T. Lockett, and Geo W. Otey; therefore, be it.

list.item: 1. Resolved, That while we latent the premature death of our comrades, yet we how with submission to the will of Him who is too wise to our and too good to be unkind and that we cherish with affectionate regard the remembrance of their many virtues and sterling qualities that not only endeared them to us, but to all who knew them.

2. Resolved, That in their death their company has lost the services of brave, generous and amiable comrades and the Government the aid of valuable and efficient soldiers, who were among the first to rush to arms, and who have testified their devotion to their country's cause by yielding their young Lyes a sacrifice in the defence.

3. Resolved, That we tender our heartfealt sympathies to the families of our deceased brother soldiers, and that He "who tempers the wind to the shorn lamb" may comfort and support them in their afflictions.
